Graphical abstract The complete oxidation of isobutane has been studied using the oxidation catalysts β-MnO2, α-Fe2O3, Co3O4 and NiO, prior to and following addition of 5wt% Au nanoparticles. The activity order is Co3O4 >β-MnO2 >α-Fe2O3, with the position of NiO dependent on the Ni3+ content which changes with temperature. Preformed n-hexanethiolate-stabilized gold nanoparticles, following adsorption and thermolysis in air, introduce a small amount of sulfur as adsorbed sulfate. The sulfate appears to block the reoxidation step in the Mars-van Krevelen mechanism. This can have a significant effect on catalytic activity, as observed for β-MnO2. TEM/STEM studies indicate that gold nanoparticles of 2–4nm in diameter form, which depends on the identity of the metal oxide and its specific surface area. Gold nanoparticle size effects have been studied on NiO, and show that the apparent activation energy and temperature of initial reaction depend on nanoparticle size. Comparisons of the multicomponent Au/MO x /γ-Al2O3 (M:Al=1:10) catalysts, where M=Mn, Fe, Co, Ni, have also been studied, and all are more active catalysts than Au/γ-Al2O3, but less active than the unsupported catalysts. Gold 4f 7/2 XPS studies on Au/MO x and Au/MO x /γ-Al2O3 have shown that the only common species present is Au(0), suggesting that higher oxidation states of Au are not important in oxidation catalysis. Keywords Gold nanoparticles Transition metal oxides Isobutane oxidation n-Alkanethiolate-stabilized gold nanoparticles Gold catalyst 1 Introduction While bulk gold metal is not catalytically active, when finely divided in the form of nanoparticles, it is well established that gold becomes highly active [1–3]. In 1987, Haruta et al. reported that when gold is deposited as nanoparticles on metal oxides, it demonstrates a surprisingly high catalytic activity for CO oxidation even at sub-ambient temperatures, as low as −70°C [4,5]. This report stimulated the study of the catalytic behaviour of gold for both industrial and environmental applications. Subsequently, gold nanoparticles have been found to exhibit a wide range of unique activities and selectivity for a number of reactions when deposited on metal oxides. These include low temperature oxidations (e.g., CO), the partial and complete oxidation of hydrocarbons, the hydrogenation of carbon oxides and the reduction of NO [3,6–8]. Gold nanoparticles are even active in the water–gas shift reaction [9]. In the case of the complete oxidation of small hydrocarbons, most studies have concentrated on the oxidation of methane using a variety of metal oxides [10–17], although the oxidation of ethane, propane and propene on various Au/MO x systems has also been reported [10,18–22]. Other studies have involved the application of gold nanoparticles supported on metal oxides for volatile organic compound control from an environmental perspective, including the complete oxidation of benzene, toluene and n-hexane, as well as functionalised organic compounds (alcohols, aldehydes, ketones, etc.) [23–29]. There are a variety of methods that may be used to load gold onto metal oxides, of which co-precipitation and deposition-precipitation using chloroauric acid as the source of gold are the most common [30]. In the deposition–precipitation method urea is generally used to raise the solution pH as it slowly hydrolyses at high temperatures (>∼80°C) thereby avoiding the formation of particulate gold hydroxide. Other synthetic approaches include co-sputtering, chemical vapour deposition and solvated metal atomic dispersion [2,6,31]. However, these methods lack control over the size of the gold nanoparticles. An alternative approach involves the adsorption of previously formed n-alkanethiolate-stabilized gold (n-CnSAu) nanoparticles, such as those synthesised by the Brust–Schiffren method [32], onto a variety of metal oxides from aprotic solvents, as described by Zheng and Stucky [33]. Other early studies include those of Pietron et al. [34], Chou and McFarland [8], Tai et al. [35], and Hickey et al. [36] who used TiO2, titania aerogels or CeO2 as support media. This approach allows the deposition of an exact amount of gold on an oxide surface as the composition (i.e., gold content) of the n-CnSAu nanoparticles can be established easily from a prior thermogravimetric analysis. Moreover, transmission electron microscopy also allows the average particle size and particle size range to be established for the parent n-CnSAu nanoparticles. Thus the above procedure allows the introduction of gold nanoparticles with a known average particle size and size distribution onto the oxide surface following direct adsorption from an aprotic solvent [37]. After isolation of the resulting solid, the thiolate component around the adsorbed gold nanoparticles is removed by controlled thermolysis in air. The adsorbed n-CnSAu nanoparticles thermally decompose at high temperatures, although for longer chain thiols the organo and organosulfur decomposition/oxidation products require higher temperatures for their removal because of strong adsorption onto the metal oxide surface [37]. Shorter n-alkanethiolate chains are therefore preferred, and n-hexanethiolate has been found to be ideal for this purpose, with complete volatilisation of the organic decomposition products at 340°C. However, this general procedure does leave some sulfur as sulfate adsorbed on the oxide surface [37,38]. Tai et al. have shown that the adsorbed sulfate can have detrimental effects on the oxidation of CO to CO2 over titania-coated silica but have reported that this may be removed by heating above 600°C in air, or 400°C in an H2/Ar atmosphere [38]. As noted above, several studies of the effects of gold nanoparticles on the complete oxidation of small hydrocarbons, primarily methane, over transition metal oxides have been reported. Waters et al., using a co-precipitation method involving sodium carbonate, showed that for a selection of transition metal oxides, complete oxidation of methane followed the sequence Au/Co3O4 >Au/NiO>Au/MnO x >Au/Fe2O3, with Au/CeO x unreactive under the reaction conditions [11]. Comparative reactivity was correlated based on the temperature of initial reaction, T i, while X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS) showed that reactivity increased with increasing amounts of oxidised gold. Conversely, Choudhary et al. prepared Au/metal oxide catalysts using the deposition–precipitation method with urea and found that Au/Fe2O3 was the most active combination for methane oxidation, followed by Au/MnO2 >Au/Al2O3 ∼Au/CeO2 ∼Au/CoO x >Au/Ga2O3 >Au/MgO>Au/TiO2 [17]. While gold particle sizes were reported, no correlation was found between catalytic activity and particle size. Indeed the most active catalyst, Au/Fe2O3, was found to have the highest gold particle size, and XPS studies on this catalyst found three different gold species present, Au0, Au1+ and Au3+. An alternative approach has been used by Nieuwenhuys and co-workers in their studies of the oxidation of methane involving supported transition metal oxides (MO x ) on high surface area γ-Al2O3, with the gold nanoparticles added by deposition-precipitation using urea [14,15]. These are multicomponent catalysts of the type Au/MOx/γ-Al2O3, where M=Cr, Mn, Fe, Co, Ni, Cu and Zn. Two studies have been made, one involving initial formation of 5wt% Au/γ-Al2O3, which was then followed by addition of the MO x component [14]. The other began with initial formation of MO x /γ-Al2O3 supports, followed by addition of the gold nanoparticles [15]. The presence of gold nanoparticles always enhanced catalytic activity, but in one study the MO x phase was found to enhance the oxidation of methane, while in the other the MO x component generally did not affect the catalytic activity compared to the parent Au/γ-Al2O3 catalyst. In both studies the gold nanoparticle sizes were quite variable depending on the identity of MO x , and there were some significant variations in particle size following reaction. Much of the particle size variation results from the fact that the complete oxidation of methane occurs at high temperatures, i.e., above about 700°C, and it is known that aggregation of gold nanoparticles accelerates markedly above 400°C on TiO2 [39]. Other studies have involved the complete oxidation of propane. Solsona et al. investigated gold on several MO x supports including CoO x (Co3O4 detected by XRD), MnO x (Mn2O3 detected by XRD), CuO, Fe2O3 and CeO2, all prepared by co-precipitation, as well as TiO2 by deposition-precipitation and both CoO x and MnO x by impregnation. The addition of gold generally resulted in a significant increase in catalytic activity. Methane and ethane were also investigated. The most active catalyst was Au/CoO x [18,19]. In these studies the gold particle size varied considerably depending on the support, and also on the method of loading. Also, the complete oxidation of propane has been studied using an Au/MnO x /TOS catalyst, where TOS represents a triple oxide support consisting of CeO2, TiO2 and ZrO2 (Ce:Ti:Zr mole ratio=1.57:1.23:1.00) [20]. Evidence for strong synergism was observed between Au and Mn from the increased catalytic activity of Au/MnO x /TOS compared to the individual Au/TOS and Au/MnO x catalysts. For the oxidation of propene Gluhoi et al. examined Au/γ-Al2O3 as a catalyst, and the effects of various metal oxides in multicomponent Au/MO x /γ-Al2O3 catalysts, where M=Ce, Mn, Fe and Co [21]. The most active catalyst was Au/CeO x /γ-Al2O3, based upon T 95%, i.e., the temperature at which 95% conversion of propene occurred, followed in order by Au/FeO x /γ-Al2O3 >Au/MnO x /γ-Al2O3 >Au/CoO x /γ-Al2O3. However, again there were variations in the gold particle sizes. Based upon diffuse reflectance UV–vis spectroscopic studies, it was concluded that gold was present as Au0. The current study extends investigations into the effects of gold nanoparticles for the complete oxidation of hydrocarbons, in this case isobutane, over a range of catalytically active metal oxides (β-MnO2, α-Fe2O3, Co3O4 and NiO) of varying acidity/basicity and also to analogous supported metal oxides, MO x (M=Mn, Fe, Co, Ni) on γ-Al2O3. Isobutane was chosen as it is the smallest saturated hydrocarbon that contains a tertiary CH bond, which will lead to high reactivity and to a low temperature for complete oxidation. This will, in turn, lead to smaller thermal effects on gold nanoparticle aggregation. Moreover, as noted above, adding gold nanoparticles using adsorption and subsequent thermolysis of n-C6SAu nanoparticles allows for the introduction of gold nanoparticles of known size and particle distribution to the metal oxide surface, which in turn allows a direct comparison of the effects of different metal oxides as supports. The evolution of gold nanoparticle sizes are thus monitored before and following catalysis. Finally, this approach allows an investigation of the different effects of the transition metal oxides MO x , where M=Mn, Fe, Co and Ni, either alone or as supported multicomponent MO x /γ-Al2O3 catalysts and produces an ordering of these oxides as regards catalytic activity for the total oxidation of the small hydrocarbon isobutane. 2 Experimental 2.1 General Chloroauric acid (HAuCl4·3H2O, Sigma–Aldrich, ≥49.0% Au), tetraoctylammonium bromide (C32H68NBr, Sigma–Aldrich, 98%), sodium borohydride (Merck), toluene (Merck, ACS reagent), methanol (Lab-scan, AR grade), n-hexane (Merck, 98%), n-hexanethiol (CH3(CH2)5SH, Sigma–Aldrich, 95%), γ-aluminium oxide (Alfa Aesar, 110μm, 99.997%), nickel oxide (black, Univar, analytical reagent), cobalt(II,III) oxide (nanoparticles, <50nm, Sigma–Aldrich, 99.8%), manganese(II) nitrate tetrahydrate (Chem-Supply, AR grade, >98.0%), iron(III) nitrate nonahydrate (APS, AR grade, 98.0–101.0%), cobalt(II) nitrate hexahydrate (Chem-Supply, AR grade, >98.0%), nickel(II) nitrate hexahydrate (Ajax Finechem, AR reagent, Univar, >98%) and silicon carbide (Sigma–Aldrich, 200–450 mesh) were used as received. The gases used for the catalysis studies were nitrogen (BOC Gases, Ultra High Purity), oxygen (BOC Gases, High Purity) and isobutane (BOC Gases, Instrument Grade). For the TG/DTA studies under reducing conditions, 10% H2/N2 (Coregas) was used. Thermogravimetric/differential thermal analyses (TG/DTA) were obtained using a PerkinElmer Diamond TG/DTA instrument. Sample masses for the n-C6SAu nanoparticles of 1.0–2.0mg were routinely used, with a heating rate of 20°Cmin−1, and were performed in a flowing air atmosphere (20mLmin−1). All other studies were obtained with 5–15mg of sample, using a heating rate of 10°Cmin−1 in a flowing air atmosphere (20mLmin−1). TG/DTA studies under 10% H2/N2 (effectively temperature programmed reduction-type studies) were obtained with a gas flow of 20mLmin−1 on 10–20mg of sample and a heating rate of 10°Cmin−1. Transmission electron microscopy (TEM) was performed on a JEOL 2100 LaB6 TEM instrument, while scanning transmission electron microscopy (STEM) was obtained on a JEOL JEM-ARM200F instrument. Samples of n-C6SAu nanoparticles, or samples that had been loaded on the metal oxides and subsequently thermolysed in air at 340°C for 1h were suspended in either n-hexane or methanol and mounted on carbon-coated copper grids and allowed to dry in the air. Spent catalyst samples, mixed with silicon carbide, were mounted using the same procedure. Histograms of the thermolysed gold metal particle sizes were obtained from at least 250–450 particles. The minimum observable size limit of the gold nanoparticles was about 1nm. Particle sizes were estimated using the program DigitalMicrograph, Gatan, Inc., CA, USA. The average particle diameters and standard deviations were calculated as described previously [37]. Solid state infrared spectra were recorded on a PerkinElmer Spectrum 2 instrument, with a diamond UATR (universal attenuated total reflectance) accessory. Corrections for ATR and baseline straightening were applied. X-Ray powder diffraction (XRD) studies were performed on a Philips X’Pert Pro multipurpose diffractometer using Ni-filtered Cu-Kα radiation. Average crystallite sizes were determined using the Scherrer equation, with the peak broadening (i.e., peak width at half height) from the crystallite size obtained using the Warren equation [40]. Laser-ablation mass spectrometric analyses were performed with an ESi NWR 213nm laser ablation system coupled to an Agilent 7700× ICP-QMS. Powdered samples were compacted at 8.5 t using a hydraulic press. Portions of the resulting discs were mounted on a resin block with double-sided adhesive tape. Spot sizes of 100μm were used to obtain a representative area, and a minimum of three analyses were carried out for each sample. The 197Au, 33S and 34S isotopes were used for the determination of Au and S, while the data were analyzed with Iolite 2.4/Igor Pro 6.3 software. BET surface areas were obtained by nitrogen adsorption at 77K (9 or 13 points) on a Micromeritics ASAP 2020 instrument. Samples were degassed at 120°C for 4h prior to analysis. X-ray photoelectron spectra were recorded on a Thermo Scientific ESCALAB250Xi instrument with an Al-Kα source (1486.68eV) operating at 13kV and 12mA. All spectra were collected using an analyser pass energy of 20eV, a step size of 0.1eV and an electron take off angle of 90°. All spectra were recorded at a pressure of better than 2×10−9 mbar. Analysis of the data was accomplished using CASA-XPS (Version 2.3.16) software, with the C 1s peak for adventitious carbon set at 285.0eV. 2.2 Preparation of n-hexanethiolate-stabilized gold nanoparticles n-C6SAu nanoparticles were synthesised using the Brust–Schiffrin method [32] and the procedure has been described previously [37]. Thermogravimetric analysis showed that the residual mass (Au) was 83%. TEM studies showed that the average particle size was 2.0±0.2nm, with a particle size range of 1.0–4.5nm. 2.3 Preparation of β-MnO2, α-Fe2O3 and Co3O4 Pyrolusite, β-MnO2, was obtained by heating commercial electrolytic manganese dioxide (Delta EMD, Australia, Pty Ltd) at 350°C for 24h in air [41], and was supplied by Prof. S. Donne. The mixed oxidation state Co3O4 of targeted surface area 20m2 g−1 was obtained by heating commercial nanoparticle Co3O4 of specific surface area 41.0m2 g−1 to 450°C for 1h. Hematite, α-Fe2O3, was synthesised by the method described by Schwertmann and Cornell involving the initial precipitation of (2-line) ferrihydrite and its subsequent transformation into α-Fe2O3 (Method 4, page 103, reference [42]). 2.4 Preparation of the transition metal oxides of manganese, iron, cobalt and nickel on γ-Al2O3 The transition metal oxides, MO x , of manganese, iron, cobalt and nickel supported on γ-Al2O3 were prepared by stirring calculated amounts of the hydrated Mn(II), Fe(III), Co(II) and Ni(II) nitrates with γ-Al2O3 (with a M:Al mole ratio of 1:10). The pH values of the resulting solutions of the M(II) nitrate/γ-Al2O3 mixtures were 6.0–6.1, while that of Fe(III)/γ-Al2O3, which formed a fine, red–brown precipitate, was 3.8. Following evaporation of the water, the resulting solids were thoroughly ground and heated at 80°C for 24h. TG/DTA studies in flowing air on the resulting solids from 25 to 500°C indicated that nitrate in all four samples decomposed from 175 to 250°C, but that a thermal process occurred at about 400°C in the case of Mn(II). Subsequently, the solids were heated in air at 150°C for 30min, then at 250°C for 30min to decompose the nitrate and finally at 340°C for 1h. The Mn(II)-containing solid was heated to 400°C for 1h in air. 2.5 Deposition of n-hexanethiolate-stabilized gold nanoparticles on metal oxides The method employed to adsorb n-C6SAu nanoparticles on metal oxides has been described previously [37], and is derived from that reported by Zheng and Stucky [33]. In a typical procedure, the calculated amount of n-C6SAu nanoparticles (based on a prior thermogravimetric analysis) required to give 5wt% of gold nanoparticles was dissolved in 3mL of n-hexane solution and added to 0.1–1.0g of metal oxide (or transition metal oxide/γ-Al2O3) in 3–5mL of n-hexane in a glass vial with vigorous stirring until the n-hexane had turned colourless. This took from minutes to hours depending on the metal oxide. Following complete adsorption of the n-C6SAu nanoparticles, the solid was allowed to settle, the colourless n-hexane removed by pipette and the solid dried in a fumehood. The resulting material was thermolyzed in air to remove the n-C6S− ligands, leaving behind gold nanoparticles on the oxide surface. The thermolysis was accomplished in several steps, involving heating at 105°C and 220°C for 15min each, and finally heating slowly to 340°C and maintaining the temperature for 1h. All thermolyzed samples were kept in sealed glass vials. 2.6 Catalysis studies Catalysis studies were performed in a flow system that was constructed from stainless steel with a quartz reactor, employing Swagelok unions with stainless steel or Teflon ferrules, as appropriate. Isobutane (and other hydrocarbons) were determined by gas chromatography, and CO2 and CO by gas-phase infrared spectroscopy. The catalysis and analysis system has been described previously [37]. The standard feed composition was 1.0mLmin−1 isobutane, with 10.0mLmin−1 oxygen and the remainder nitrogen, respectively, with a total flow of 50.0mLmin−1. For each study 0.10g of catalyst was used. So as to provide sufficient temperature control, given the highly exothermic nature of the oxidation reaction, the solid catalyst was physically mixed with 0.50g of SiC (200–450 mesh), resulting in a contact time of 0.6s and a space velocity of 30,000mLh−1 g-cat−1. All catalysis studies involved stepping through sequential rises in temperature using a heating rate of 10°Cmin−1, and allowing the system to equilibrate for 10–15min at each temperature followed by GC analysis of the residual isobutane from the outflow from the reactor. This generally involved two to four separate GC determinations at each temperature, to confirm that the equilibration had been achieved. The collected data at each temperature were averaged. The oxidation products CO2 and CO were determined by gas-phase infrared spectroscopy at about 18–23% conversion and also at 100% conversion of isobutane. On completion of a catalysis run the isobutane and oxygen were turned off and the catalyst was allowed to cool in a nitrogen atmosphere. Spent catalysts were stored in sealed vials. 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Total oxidation of isobutane over oxidation catalysts: β-MnO2, α-Fe2O3, Co3O4 and NiO The four first-row transition metals whose oxides have been reported to show enhanced catalytic activity after addition of gold nanoparticles for the complete oxidation of methane are those of Mn, Fe, Co and Ni [11,14]. However, the actual oxide was not necessarily identified in these studies. Likewise, oxides based on Mn, Fe and Co have been used for the oxidation of propane and ethane [18,19]. Oxides of these same transition metals would be expected to be active for isobutane oxidation, and it has been demonstrated previously that NiO is active for the complete oxidation of this alkane [37]. Four oxides of the above transition metals were therefore studied, with and without added gold nanoparticles (5wt%). These included β-MnO2, α-Fe2O3, Co3O4 and NiO. All four are thermally stable in air to high temperatures, with the exception of β-MnO2, which decomposes to Mn2O3 at 535°C [43]. The theoretical optical basicities (Λ th) [44–46], specific surface areas and average crystallite sizes (based on the Scherrer equation) for the four metal oxides are given in Table 1 . The theoretical optical basicities indicate that all four are relatively basic oxides. Note that the Λ th values are those for the bulk solids, with no account taken of how these values change at the oxide surface [45,46]. Also, to eliminate the effects of differences in specific surface area of the metal oxides both on their catalytic reactions towards isobutane oxidation without gold nanoparticles, as well as on possible gold nanoparticle aggregation, Co3O4 and β-MnO2 were synthesised or obtained with comparable specific surface areas to that of the commercially available NiO. Preliminary catalytic oxidation studies with α-Fe2O3 indicated that it was the least active of the four metal oxide catalysts, so material of this oxide was used that had a higher surface area than the other three oxides. This did not affect the ordering of the oxides as regards their relative catalytic activities (see below). The XRD patterns (2θ =20–80°) of the four oxides used for the catalysis studies are shown in the Supplementary data, Fig. S1. The catalysis data for the four metal oxides are given in Table 2 , and includes values for the initial reaction temperature (T i), the 100% conversion temperature (T 100%), the apparent activation energy (E app), and the product distributions of CO2 and CO at about 20% conversion and at 100% conversion of isobutane. The % conversion-temperature plots for β-MnO2, α-Fe2O3, Co3O4 and NiO [37] are shown in Fig. 1 , and selected rates of reaction at 220 and 270°C, which also allow comparison of the catalysts, are given in the Supplementary data, Table S1. XRD studies of these metal oxide catalysts following complete oxidation of isobutane indicated that they had not changed structure. In particular, the β-MnO2 showed no evidence of thermal decomposition. Previously, Co3O4 has been shown to be highly active for the oxidation of methane [11,14] and propane [18,19], and the same was found in the present study for isobutane. The % conversion-temperature plot for Co3O4 demonstrates that at about 10–15% conversion, the reaction rate increases dramatically to 100% conversion. This initially suggested a lack of temperature control. However, attempts to control the reaction by increased dilution with SiC or the use of Co3O4 nanoparticles (average crystallite size 23nm, specific surface area 41m2 g−1), which might be expected to dissipate heat more quickly, exhibited the same behaviour. Thus while both T i and T 100% are listed in Table 2, E app is not regarded as truly representative of this oxide and thus is not included. Co3O4 is known to adsorb molecular oxygen, with increasing uptake as the temperature is increased [19]. This stems from extensive oxygen lattice defects, which can be replenished by O2 at higher temperatures. Also, it has been shown that Co3O4 has oxygen storage/release capacity [19,47], whereby catalysts store oxygen in the bulk under oxidising conditions, but release oxygen under reducing conditions. Both of these factors are likely to play a role in the high reactivity of Co3O4 with increasing temperature. Comparison of the catalysis data (Tables 2 and S1) for β-MnO2, α-Fe2O3, Co3O4 and NiO shows that different orderings of the relative catalytic activities of the four oxides are found depending on the criterion used. Based on the lowest value of T i the order is Co3O4 ∼β-MnO2 >NiO>α-Fe2O3, while for 100% conversion of isobutane to CO2 the order of activity is Co3O4 >β-MnO2 >α-Fe2O3 >NiO. For E app, the order (based on the smallest E app) is NiO>β-MnO2 >α-Fe2O3. The relative rates of reaction (Supplementary data, Table S1) support these relative orders of activity. It is not immediately obvious which criterion should be used, despite the use of oxides of (mostly) comparable specific surface area, and with all having very similar average crystallite sizes (Table 1). However, close examination of the data indicates that it is NiO that is shifting significantly relative to the other three oxides. Black NiO is known to be non-stoichiometric, with a small amount of Ni3+ included as part of the lattice [48,49]. On heating to progressively higher temperatures in air it is known that the amount of Ni3+ in NiO steadily decreases [48], but also that at low temperatures Ni3+ can be formed in the presence of oxygen [50]. Sintering of NiO at 1000°C in air gives a composition close to stoichiometric [49]. Thus Ni3+ is less stabilized in NiO at progressively higher temperatures. A temperature programmed reduction (TPR) study of NiO has shown that Ni3+ (surface and bulk) can be detected when NiO is prepared at lower temperatures [50]. Based on the relationship between Ni3+ content and crystallite size, which is related to the temperature of its formation [49], there was close to 1at% of Ni3+ in the commercial NiO used in the present studies. However, higher Ni3+ contents have been measured during formation of NiO, with values up to 5.9at% depending on the temperature of preparation [49]. It is generally agreed that the mechanism of oxidation of alkanes over metal oxides occurs by a Mars-van Krevelen reaction sequence. It therefore seems reasonable to assume that at lower temperatures, e.g., at T i, the Ni3+ at the surface is capable of participating in a Mars-van Krevelen reaction mechanism but that as the temperature rises, the presence of Ni3+ is less favourable, reducing the fraction available for reaction and thereby reducing the relative catalytic activity of NiO (e.g., at T 100%). Assuming that the redox cycle between Ni3+ and Ni2+ is more likely to occur than that between Ni2+ and Ni, and that there is very fast reoxidation of Ni2+ to Ni3+ under the catalysis conditions, the contribution from Ni3+ ↔Ni2+ reduction–oxidation would become progressively less important at higher temperatures. When the O2:isobutane ratio was increased from 10:1 to 15:1 in an attempt to increase the amount of Ni3+, the T i, T 100% and E app data (Table 2) remained essentially unchanged. This suggests that O2 is involved in fast replenishment of oxide in the NiO structure following oxidation of isobutane, as well as reoxidation of Ni2+ to Ni3+, which is governed by the temperature. Examination of the CO2:CO ratio for all four metal oxides shows that there was substantial CO formed at about 20% conversion, but that at 100% conversion of isobutane the main oxidation product was always CO2 (>98.8%). Not surprisingly, in the study of NiO involving the higher O2:isobutane ratio, the CO2:CO ratio was greater at both ∼20% and 100% conversion. To provide further information about the reducibility of the four metal oxides, TG/DTA studies were made under a reducing atmosphere of 10% H2/N2. This data provides complimentary information to TPR studies on these metal oxides [18,19,50–57]. The TG/DTA data are listed in Table 3 , and the TGA and DTA profiles are shown in the Supplementary data, Fig. S2. The thermal processes indicated in Table 3 have been taken from those reported in the literature [18,19,50–57], and the % mass losses observed agree with these thermal reduction steps. Note that there are two pathways for reduction of α-Fe2O3 depending on the temperature and either a three-step or a two-step mechanism can be invoked [57]. However, this concerns the reduction of Fe3O4, which is the initial reduction product of α-Fe2O3, and occurs to higher temperatures. The temperature of initial mass loss, i.e., involving loss of lattice oxygen, should closely parallel the initial peak observed in the corresponding TPR study, and yields the order Co3O4 ∼β-MnO2 <NiO<α-Fe2O3. This order follows that of T i (Table 2), although there is a difference of some 20–60°C between T i and the temperature of initial mass loss in the TG/DTA studies. As pointed out by Solsona et al. [18], TPR results and the reduction/oxidation properties of catalytic reactions (the Mars-van Krevelen mechanism) are related, but are not the same. In TPR experiments (and this will also apply to the TG/DTA studies) the oxidation step of the catalytic cycle is missing and H2 is not the gaseous substrate employed in the catalysis studies. Note also that the TG/DTA data for NiO does not appear to be sensitive enough to indicate the presence of Ni3+, either on the surface or in the bulk. Direct comparisons of the TG/DTA data with the published TPR data are difficult because of a range of temperature ramps employed, and the fact that specific surface areas and hence particle sizes also play a role in the locations of the TPR peaks [18,19,50–57], and also will affect the TG/DTA studies. However, the published TPR data does indicate that Co3O4 is the most active catalyst. 3.2 Total oxidation of isobutane over Au/β-MnO2, Au/α-Fe2O3, Au/Co3O4 and Au/NiO—evolution of Au nanoparticle sizes from initial thermolysis to spent catalysts Addition of 5wt% gold nanoparticles to the same four oxides had different effects on T i, T 100% and E app depending on the metal oxide. The data are included in Table 2, and the % conversion-temperature plots for Au/β-MnO2, Au/α-Fe2O3, Au/Co3O4 and Au/NiO [37] are shown in Fig. 2 . A comparison of relative reaction rates at 250 and 410°C has been included in the Supplementary data, Table S1. In general, the introduction of gold nanoparticles (e.g., by co-precipitation or impregnation methods) to metal oxides leads to an increase in catalytic activity, as has been observed for methane, ethane or propane [11,17,18]. This involves decreases in both T i and T 100%. As noted above, the introduction of the gold nanoparticles using preformed n-C n SAu (or related) nanoparticles introduces a small amount of sulfur as adsorbed sulfate as part of the thermolysis process [37,38,58]. It is well known that metal oxide surfaces can be poisoned by sulfur oxides and sulfur-containing compounds in catalytic reactions [59,60]. Consequently, it might be expected that the residual sulfur introduced by use of n-C6SAu nanoparticles could have some observable effects. In studies to date, it has been found that the oxidation of CO to CO2 was completely quenched using a titania-coated silica aerogel, but that activity could be established by removal of the sulfur at 650°C in air or by reduction in H2/Ar at 400°C [38]. However, it has also been shown that in the complete oxidation of isobutane over Au/NiO, the adsorbed sulfate appeared to have no apparent effect, and while TiO2 (both anatase and rutile) were unreactive towards isobutane oxidation, Au/anatase and Au/rutile were active oxidation catalysts even in the presence of the introduced sulfate [37]. Thus different effects appear to occur depending on the metal oxide or support. Of the four metal oxides studied, the data for 5wt% Au/NiO have been reported previously [37]. Briefly, on introduction of the gold nanoparticles, T i decreased slightly compared to the parent NiO, although T 100% remained essentially unchanged. Also, E app was lowered substantially from about 89 to 51kJ/mol. Overall, the effects were on T i and E app. For 5wt% Au/α-Fe2O3 compared to α-Fe2O3 in the present studies, both T i and E app decreased, while T 100% again remained about the same. E app also decreased significantly, as found for Au/NiO. Thus both Au/NiO and Au/α-Fe2O3 behave similarly relative to NiO and α-Fe2O3, respectively. Moreover, the relative ordering regarding T i and T 100% for Au/NiO and Au/α-Fe2O3 is the same as for NiO and α-Fe2O3. Thus the presence of adsorbed sulfate appears to have had little effect in these two catalyst systems. For both 5wt% Au/Co3O4 and Au/β-MnO2 the effects of introduction of the gold nanoparticles on the catalysis results were different to those found for Au/NiO and Au/α-Fe2O3. For Au/Co3O4 compared to Co3O4, T i did not change, but T 100% increased (E app is again not reported for the reason given above). However, despite these changes, Au/Co3O4 was still more active than both Au/NiO and Au/α-Fe2O3. The results for 5wt% Au/β-MnO2 were particularly unusual, in that T i was found to be much higher than for any of the other Au/MO x catalysts as well as for β-MnO2, and the % conversion only reached 50% by about 600°C. There was an inflection point at 520–540°C, but this was almost certainly associated with the thermal decomposition of β-MnO2 into Mn2O3 [43]. This was supported by recycling the used catalyst, and the inflection point no longer occurred. For both 5wt% Au/Co3O4 and Au/β-MnO2 the catalysis data suggest some poisoning effect was present, and which was highly significant for the latter. The most likely cause of this was from the presence of sulfur as adsorbed sulfate as a result of the thermal oxidative decomposition of the n-C6SAu− ligands of the adsorbed n-C6SAu nanoparticles. Thus it is likely that the amount of sulfur as sulfate remaining on the catalyst surface was enough to cause the observed behaviour in both Au/Co3O4 and Au/β-MnO2, but not enough to completely quench the catalysis. The CO2:CO ratios for all four Au/MO x catalysts indicate that there was substantial CO formed at about 20% conversion of isobutane, while for those that reached 100% conversion (i.e., not β-MnO2) the main product was primarily CO2 (>98.8%). The presence of adsorbed sulfate on an oxide surface can be observed easily by FT-IR attenuated total reflectance (ATR) spectroscopy [37]. The three 5wt% Au/MO x catalysts (M=Mn, Fe and Co) prior to catalysis were examined and the spectra in the ν(SO) stretching region (1350–850cm−1) are shown in Fig. 3 , while the data are listed in Table 4 . Also included in Table 4 and Fig. 3 are the data for NiO, which has been published previously [37]. All four metal oxides showed the presence of adsorbed sulfate as expected. The triply-degenerate infrared active ν 3(SO) stretch for SO4 2− in a symmetrical environment (T d) is found at about 1130–1140cm−1 [61]. Splitting of this mode occurs on lowering the symmetry. These multiple ν(SO) peaks are found over the range 1250–1000cm−1 [61]. Sulfate adsorbed on an oxide surface is likely to have three (C3v ) or two (C2v ) bridging oxygen atoms, giving two and three peaks, respectively [37]. The data in Table 4 indicates the presence of adsorbed sulfate for all four 5wt% Au/MO x systems with multiple environments likely for Au/Co3O4. The residual sulfur on the Au/MO x catalysts following thermolysis was measured using laser-ablation mass spectrometry, relative to the initial amount of sulfur adsorbed from the parent n-C6SAu nanoparticles. The results are given in Table 5 . Also included is the residual weight percentage of sulfur following thermolysis. After initial adsorption of the n-C6SAu nanoparticles onto β-MnO2, α-Fe2O3, Co3O4 and NiO, the amount of sulfur present was 0.28wt%. On thermolysis however, this was reduced to a range of 0.19–0.24wt%. There appears to be a correlation of the residual sulfur (as sulfate) with the relative catalytic activities of the four Au/MO x catalysts (Table 2). This is particularly evident for Au/β-MnO2 which does have the highest residual sulfur and did exhibit the greatest effect from the presence of sulfate in the catalysis studies. Note, however, that the range of residual weight percent is not great. Previously, it has been shown that for 5wt% Au/NiO, sulfur is retained as sulfate when n-CnSAu nanoparticles (n =6, 12, 16) were used as the source of the gold nanoparticles [37]. Some sulfur is lost during the thermolysis process, which is used to remove the stabilizing n-alkylthiolate ligands and is performed in air, but most is retained and at higher temperatures is converted into adsorbed sulfate. In the case of the complete oxidation of isobutane by 5wt% Au/NiO, as reported previously [37], the residual sulfate had no or little apparent effect, although addition of a further equivalent of sulfate (as Na2SO4) corresponding to the amount of sulfur added originally by adsorption of the n-C6SAu nanoparticles completely quenched the oxidation catalysis. It is apparent that the critical amount of sulfur must be about 0.3–0.5wt% in order to fully quench oxidation catalysis, but that smaller amounts may be tolerated. However, this appears to depend on the metal oxide, based on the behaviour of Au/Co3O4 and Au/β-MnO2 (Table 5). The presence of some sulfate, although not enough to quench the catalysis, may also have affected the T 100% values for NiO and α-Fe2O3, making them comparable to the analogous values in the absence of the added gold nanoparticles. However, this requires further study. It is suspected that strong adsorption of sulfate on Co3O4 may be related to the presence of (surface) oxygen vacancies in the structure [19], and for β-MnO2 to the poor stacking of planes along the (110) direction (see the Supplementary data, Fig. S1(a) for the XRD pattern of β-MnO2). To investigate the reducibility of the 5wt% Au/MO x catalysts, TG/DTA studies were performed under a 10% H2/N2 atmosphere. The results are given in Table 3 and the TGA and DTA profiles are shown in the Supplementary data, Fig. S3. Relative to their parent oxides, the temperature of initial mass loss decreased for Au/β-MnO2, Au/α-Fe2O3 and Au/Co3O4, but surprisingly increased for Au/NiO. Previously, TPR studies of 3–5wt% Au/α-Fe2O3 [18,53,54] and 3wt% Au/Co3O4 [18,19] have shown that the presence of gold lowered the temperature of the first reduction peaks when the gold was loaded by co-precipitation. However, when loaded by impregnation, Au/Co3O4 showed a slight increase for the first reduction peak [18]. Similar studies on 3wt% Au/CuO and 5wt% Au/CeO2 also showed temperature reductions in their TPR peaks relative to their parent oxides using co-precipitation of gold [18]. Interestingly, however, for Mn2O3, almost no change in temperature was observed in the first reduction peak following addition of 3wt% gold by co-precipitation, while an increase in the first reduction peak was observed when the gold was introduced by impregnation [18]. It would appear that different approaches to the introduction of gold nanoparticles can lead to either a decrease or an increase in the temperature required for reduction in TPR studies. Thus the difference observed for NiO and Au/NiO in the present TG/DTA studies under 10% H2/N2 compared to the other metal oxides may not be unusual, despite the use of the same approach to load the gold nanoparticles in all four cases. The order for increasing temperature of the initial mass loss of lattice oxygen was Au/β-MnO2 <Au/Co3O4 <Au/α-Fe2O3 <Au/NiO. This order is slightly different to that found above for the parent MO x catalysts, which was β-MnO2 ∼Co3O4 <NiO<α-Fe2O3. Based on the changes in the temperatures for the initial mass loss of lattice oxygen in the TG/DTA reduction studies (Table 3), the addition of gold nanoparticles should have increased the catalytic activities of β-MnO2, Co3O4 and α-Fe2O3, but decreased that of NiO. However, the expected catalytic activity order bears no relationship to the actual orders observed for any of the parameters for the Au/MO x catalysis studies (Table 2). As noted above, the presence of residual sulfur as sulfate, even at such low amounts, appears to have had a significant effect on the catalysis studies, particularly for Au/β-MnO2. In the TG/DTA reduction studies in 10% H2/N2, however, the presence of small amounts of sulfate does not seem to have affected the loss of lattice oxygen from the catalyst (except perhaps for NiO) and hence the reducibility of the metal (which is the first step in a Mars-van Krevelen mechanism), so that in the catalysis studies the presence of sulfate likely has affected the rate at which the catalyst is regenerated (the reoxidation step in a Mars-van Krevelen mechanism). Presumably the presence of adsorbed sulfate blocks the readsorption of oxygen and hence retards regeneration of the catalyst. An important aim of the present studies was to trace the effects of changes in the gold nanoparticle sizes on complete oxidation of isobutane using the four metal oxides. Thus the gold nanoparticle sizes were determined by TEM or STEM studies both following initial thermolysis at 340°C in air to remove the n-C6S− stabilizing ligands and after their respective catalysis studies. The data (particle size range and average particle size), including those for NiO [37], are given in Table 6 . STEM images and particle size distributions of the gold nanoparticles on β-MnO2, α-Fe2O3 and Co3O4 after thermolysis at 340°C for 1h in air are shown in Figs. 4–6 , respectively. The analogous figure for Au/NiO has been published previously [37]. Examination of the data shows that the gold nanoparticle sizes following thermolysis at 340°C in air for 1h depend on the metal oxide even though the thermolysis conditions were identical in each case. This is also despite the same n-C6SAu nanoparticles being used in all of the studies, with the same average particle diameter and same particle size range. For the four metal oxides, the average gold nanoparticle size showed some variation, 2.2–3.1nm, as did the particle size ranges. This likely reflects both the specific surface area and the strength of the interaction of the gold nanoparticles with the oxide surface, which may depend on the defect concentration on the oxide surface. Notably the smallest particle size range and lowest average particle size were exhibited by α-Fe2O3, which had the highest specific surface area (Table 1), although the differences are not great. The largest particle size ranges and average particle sizes were exhibited by β-MnO2, which has poor structural ordering of the (110) planes. It is also apparent that the initial size of the gold nanoparticles, which are all relatively similar following thermolysis, cannot be the cause of the great variations in catalytic activity discussed above. However, it was following catalysis that the major differences in gold nanoparticle size occurred. Gold nanoparticles are known to aggregate on heating, especially above 400°C [39]. The STEM images and gold particle size distributions following catalysis are shown in the Supplementary data, Fig. S4–S7. In the present studies, those Au/MO x catalysts that were heated to 400°C and above showed increases in average particle size. The principal example was Au/β-MnO2, which was heated to about 600°C, but even Au/Co3O4, which had the lowest T 100% value (Table 6), showed some increase in average particle size following catalysis. Thus the gold nanoparticle sizes appear to be tracking the T 100% temperatures reached in the catalysis studies. To explore the effect of gold nanoparticle size further, the complete oxidation of isobutane over 5wt% Au/NiO was studied with different sized gold nanoparticles. In this study the metal oxide surface area was kept constant and the size of the gold nanoparticles was increased by a prior thermal treatment of identical samples of the original 5wt% Au/NiO catalyst to generate different gold nanoparticle sizes. The nanoparticle size data is given in Table 6, both prior to and following catalysis, and the catalysis data are listed in Table 7 . From the data in Tables 6 and 7 there was a progressive increase in T i and E app with increasing gold nanoparticle size, while T 100% remained unaffected. There was also little effect on the % conversions at about 20 and 100% conversion of isobutane. Note also that the average gold nanoparticle size increased for each of the spent catalysts by 0.6–0.8nm, but that the same trend in particle size remained. Significant CO was produced at about 20% conversion, but at 100% conversion the main oxidation product was CO2 (>98.5%). It is also evident that E app merely reflects the gold nanoparticle size. The same effect of gold particle size on E app has been observed previously by Griesel et al. for the oxidation of CH4 over Au/γ-Al2O3 [13]. In view of the results obtained above, including the effect of adsorbed sulfur as sulfate on the oxidation catalysis, it was decided to further explore the same four metal oxides, but now supported on a traditional oxide support for the oxidation of isobutane. For this purpose γ-Al2O3 was chosen, allowing further comparisons with previously reported studies using Au/MOx/γ-Al2O3 composite catalysts for the complete oxidation of methane and propene [14,15,21]. 3.3 Total oxidation of isobutane over 5wt% Au/MO x /γ-Al2O3 composite catalysts (M=Mn, Fe, Co Ni)—evolution of Au nanoparticle sizes from initial thermolysis to spent catalysts The oxide support used in these studies was γ-Al2O3, an acid support, which has a theoretical optical basicity, Λ th, of 0.50 [46]. Previously Nieuwenhuys and co-workers have used γ-Al2O3 to support transition metal oxides together with gold metal nanoparticles for the oxidation of methane [13–15]. A similar approach was used in the present studies, with the mole ratio of M:Al set at 1:10 for the supported metal oxides. Data on the resulting solids is given in Table 8 . Examination of the MOx/γ-Al2O3 solids by XRD showed the presence of NiO, Co3O4 and β-MnO2 along with γ-Al2O3, but no evidence of any XRD pattern was observed for an Fe(III)-containing compound in FeO x /γ-Al2O3. The XRD patterns (2θ =20–80°) are shown in the Supplementary data, Fig. S8, along with that of γ-Al2O3. Presumably the FeO x crystallite sizes were too small to provide an XRD pattern, although an amorphous phase cannot be ruled out. Thus while the identity of the Fe(III) oxide is unknown, it is most likely α-Fe2O3 as known Fe(III) oxyhydroxides (e.g., ferrihydrite, goethite, lepidocrocite, etc.) convert to this species on thermal treatment [42,62]. There was no evidence for the formation of Al(III)-containing spinel structures, such as NiAl2O4. The MO x /γ-Al2O3 supports were subsequently loaded with n-C6SAu nanoparticles and thermolyzed at 340°C for 1h in air to give the 5wt% Au/MO x /γ-Al2O3 composite catalysts. FT-IR (ATR) studies (1300–950cm−1) indicated only a single, broad peak that occurred at 1120–1125cm−1 for all four catalysts. The spectra are shown in the Supplementary data, Fig. S9. These are almost identical to that of the broad peak that is found in the absence of MO x (1121cm−1 [37], see also Fig. S9). No evidence for ν(SO) stretches was found that could be assigned to sulfate on a MO x phase (Table 4). However, it should be cautioned that the MO x phases were only present at a level of about 10mol% and that multiple ν(SO) stretches may not be observable. The catalysis data for the MO x /γ-Al2O3 and 5wt% Au/MO x /γ-Al2O3 studies are listed in Table 9 and the sizes of the gold nanoparticles, prior to and following catalysis for the Au/MO x /γ-Al2O3 studies, are given in Table 6. The % conversion-temperature curves for all four MO x /γ-Al2O3 studies as well as γ-Al2O3 are provided in the Supplementary data, Fig. S10, while those for 5wt% Au/MO x /γ-Al2O3, together with 5wt% Au/γ-Al2O3 and γ-Al2O3 are shown in Fig. 7 . An expansion of the plot from 0 to 15% conversion (100–500°C) for Fig. 7 allowing better resolution of T i is provided in the Supplementary data, Fig. S11. Selected rates of reaction at 320 and 395°C for the MO x /γ-Al2O3 studies and at 310 and 440°C for the 5wt% Au/MO x /γ-Al2O3 studies are given in the Supplementary data, Table S2. This data also allows comparison of the relative catalytic activities of the composite catalysts. The parent γ-Al2O3 support was found to be an active catalyst at high temperatures, which is surprising, as complete oxidation generally requires more basic oxides [45,46]. However, at higher temperatures methane is known to oxidise over γ-Al2O3, and the reaction is also known to be enhanced by the addition of gold nanoparticles [13]. Careful examination of the product species shows that some isobutene was formed from about 370°C onwards, reaching a maximum at 520°C, but which disappeared by 650°C. It was, however, never detectable in high concentrations (<5%), which suggests that if it is the initial product of reaction, it is also being oxidised over γ-Al2O3. Also, at higher temperatures (>∼470°C) several smaller fragment species progressively appeared (<5%), including propene, ethene and ethane. There must be a set of fragmentation reactions to generate these three smaller molecular weight species. These too were oxidised over γ-Al2O3. While 100% conversion of isobutane occurred by 650°C, these lighter fragments persisted until about 680°C, when the only detectable products were CO2 and CO. Addition of MO x to γ-Al2O3 to give the MO x /γ-Al2O3 composite catalysts always reduced T i and T 100% relative to γ-Al2O3, but increased E app. The CO2:CO ratios indicated that significantly more CO2 formed at both about 20% and 100% conversion of isobutane for the four composite catalysts than for γ-Al2O3. The activity order based on T i and T 100% is Co3O4/γ-Al2O3 > β-MnO2/γ-Al2O3 > FeO x /γ-Al2O3, with NiO/γ-Al2O3 again variable in position, indicating the effect of the Ni3+ in NiO as has been discussed previously. Based on the E app values, the most active catalysts are Co3O4/γ-Al2O3 and β-MnO2/γ-Al2O3, followed by NiO/γ-Al2O3 and then FeOx/γ-Al2O3, although the differences are not large. The orders therefore generally reflect the relative activities of the unsupported catalysts. Note, however, that the T i and T 100% values were lower for the unsupported catalysts (Table 2) than for the MO x /γ-Al2O3 composite catalysts, indicating that there was no advantage gained in using supported catalysts on γ-Al2O3 for the complete oxidation of isobutane. On addition of 5wt% gold nanoparticles to γ-Al2O3 both T i and T 100% were significantly lowered, although E app increased slightly. However, there was no evidence for isobutene formation, or for smaller hydrocarbon fragments. The isobutene, if it formed in the presence of gold nanoparticles, was presumably instantly oxidised on formation, as were the smaller hydrocarbon fragments. The CO2:CO ratios at about 20 and 100% conversion also increased markedly, as expected from the presence of the gold nanoparticles, although even at 100% conversion of isobutane some CO was still formed (∼3%). The presence of a small amount of sulfate in this case did not appear to have a major effect, and certainly did not quench the catalytic activity which had been enhanced by the addition of the gold nanoparticles. For all four 5wt% Au/MO x /γ-Al2O3 composite catalysts the values of T i, T 100% and E app were reduced compared to the parent 5wt% Au/γ-Al2O3 catalyst. Notably, the introduction of the MO x phases always had a beneficial effect on catalytic activity. The effect of addition of MO x again produced orders in activities that were found to depend on the catalysis criteria, although the differences among the four 5wt% Au/MO x /γ-Al2O3 catalysts were not great. Based on T i the activity order is Au/Co3O4/γ-Al2O3 >Au/NiO/γ-Al2O3 >Au/β-MnO2/γ-Al2O3 ∼Au/FeO x /γ-Al2O3, while for T 100% it is Au/Co3O4/γ-Al2O3 ∼Au/β-MnO2/γ-Al2O3 ∼Au/FeO x /γ-Al2O3 >Au/NiO/γ-Al2O3. As found in the original studies of the four MO x catalysts, NiO shifted significantly relative to the other three MO x species, again presumably from the varying presence of Ni3+ in NiO with temperature. Comparisons with the related 5wt% Au/MO x unsupported catalysts are limited because of the effect of sulfate on both Au/β-MnO2 and Au/Co3O4, but the relative orders between Au/NiO/γ-Al2O3 and Au/FeO x /γ-Al2O3 for T i, T 100% and E app are consistent with the data for Au/NiO and Au/α-Fe2O3. However, of more interest is a comparison of the activities of the MO x /γ-Al2O3 and 5wt% Au/MO x /γ-Al2O3 composite catalysts. Based on the shifts in T i and T 100% (Table 9), it is apparent that Au/Co3O4/γ-Al2O3 and Au/β-MnO2/γ-Al2O3 are less active than Co3O4/γ-Al2O3 and β-MnO2/γ-Al2O3, respectively, while Au/FeO x /γ-Al2O3 (based on the shift of T i) and Au/NiO/γ-Al2O3 are more active than FeO x /γ-Al2O3 and NiO/γ-Al2O3, respectively. Remarkably, however, E app always decreased on addition of the gold nanoparticles. These results suggest that the presence of adsorbed sulfur as sulfate has had a significant effect on several catalysts. Notably, the composite catalysts Au/β-MnO2/γ-Al2O3 and Au/Co3O4/γ-Al2O3, both of which showed reductions in their catalytic behaviour relative to the catalysts without added gold nanoparticles, contain the same two transition metal oxides that exhibited unfavourable effects from the presence of sulfate in the absence of γ-Al2O3 as a support. Thus both FeO x (as α-Fe2O3) and NiO appear less susceptible to sulfate poisoning than do β-MnO2 and Co3O4. It is again evident that the presence of small amounts of adsorbed sulfate is tolerated differently by the catalytically active transition metal oxides used in this study. The average gold nanoparticle sizes of the 5wt% Au/MO x /γ-Al2O3 multicomponent catalysts following thermolysis at 340°C in air for 1h (Table 6) generally reflect the specific surface areas of the supports (Table 8). The STEM images and gold particle size distributions are shown in Figs. 8–11 , and the corresponding images and particle size distributions following catalysis in Figs. S11–14. Following catalysis, the average gold nanoparticle sizes increased by 0.3–0.4nm, except for Au/NiO/γ-Al2O3 which increased by 1.0nm. This is not surprising as all catalysts have been heated to above 400°C, and it is known that nanoparticle aggregation accelerates above this temperature [39]. The NiO-containing catalyst showed the largest increase in nanoparticle size as it was heated to the highest temperature. The average gold nanoparticle sizes thus generally reflect the specific surface areas of the catalysts, in combination with the T 100% values. This suggests that the determining factors regarding gold nanoparticle size are the nature of the support (MO x or γ-Al2O3), including the specific surface area, both of which control the size of the adsorbed gold nanoparticles upon initial thermolysis, and the maximum temperature of the reaction (i.e., T 100%). The one exception to this is Au/γ-Al2O3, which showed little increase in average gold nanoparticle size following catalysis, and which in turn suggests that there is a contribution that depends on the presence and identity of the MO x phase. This could be associated with local exothermic temperature effects on gold nanoparticle aggregation that would occur on the more catalytically active MO x components compared to the γ-Al2O3 support phase. The data reported above for the Au/MO x /γ-Al2O3 composite catalysts may be compared with previous studies on the oxidation of propene and methane by Nieuwenhuys and co-workers [14,15,21]. For propene oxidation the multicomponent Au/MO x /γ-Al2O3 catalysts (4.3–4.4wt% Au), where M=Mn, Fe and Co gave an activity order based on T 95% (i.e., 95% conversion) of Au/FeOx/γ-Al2O3 >Au/MnO x /γ-Al2O3 >Au/CoO x /γ-Al2O3 [21]. This order is different to that obtained in the present studies for the same three transition metals (M). However, the MO x phases were not identified and the M:Al atomic ratio was 1:15 rather than 1:10 as in the present studies. Moreover, there was considerable variation in the sizes of the gold nanoparticles depending on MO x , with the sizes increasing in the order FeO x <CoO x <MnO x , as determined by XRD. The small size of the gold nanoparticles may have played a significant role in the activity of the Au/FeO x /γ-Al2O3 catalyst for the complete oxidation of propene. For methane oxidation, the catalysis results were found to depend on the relative ordering of the gold nanoparticles and the MO x phase when added to the γ-Al2O3 support during synthesis [14,15]. Thus when the MO x phase was added to preformed 5wt% Au/γ-Al2O3 the order of catalytic activity was MnO x >FeO x >CoO x >NiO x for the four transition metals examined in the present studies, based on the lowest temperature for the maximum rate of reaction. The M:Al atomic ratio was again 1:15, and the average gold nanoparticle size varied from 4.3 to 6.6nm following catalysis as determined by XRD. Note however, that the criterion for comparison of activity used is different to that employed in the present studies, and again the identities of the MO x phases were not established. Also, the temperatures used (up to ∼700°C) were much higher than those required for the oxidation of isobutane, which may have had some effect on the identities of the MO x phases, and certainly on the average sizes of the gold nanoparticles. Moreover, the small range for the average gold nanoparticle sizes suggest that they were primarily associated with the γ-Al2O3 rather than the MO x phase, which is in keeping with the synthetic method employed. In contrast, when the gold nanoparticles (Au:M=1:5) were added to the MO x /γ-Al2O3 phases (M:Al=1:15), it was observed that the presence of MO x did not improve methane oxidation relative to the mono-component catalyst, i.e., Au/γ-Al2O3, although some small synergic effect was observed for MnO x and FeO x . The identities of the MO x phases for M=Mn and Co were established as Mn2O3 or Mn3O4 and Co3O4, respectively, while the average sizes of the gold nanoparticles for the Au/MO x /γ-Al2O3 catalysts prior to catalysis were 5–10nm, as determined by XRD line broadening, and which increased to 10–13nm following the oxidation of methane. The E app for Au/γ-Al2O3 was also lower than those observed for the Au/MO x /γ-Al2O3 catalysts, and it was concluded that because of the wide variation in gold nanoparticle sizes, no inferences could be drawn regarding the effect of the added MO x on E app for the Au/MO x /γ-Al2O3 composite catalysts. 3.4 X-Ray photoelectron studies of 5wt% Au/β-MnO2, Au/α-Fe2O3, Au/Co3O4 and Au/NiO catalysts and 5wt% Au/MO x /γ-Al2O3 (M=Mn, Fe, Co, Ni) composite catalysts before and after oxidation of isobutane Gold 4f 7/2 XPS studies were undertaken to establish the oxidation states of gold for the 5wt% Au/MO x and 5wt% Au/MO x /γ-Al2O3 multicomponent catalysts following oxidation of isobutane. Some studies were also made prior to catalysis, following thermolysis at 340°C for 1h in air to remove the n-C6S− ligands on the gold nanoparticles. The 4f 7/2 XPS data are listed in Table 10 , along with the data for 5wt% Au/γ-Al2O3. The 4f 7/2-5/2 XPS spectra for the Au/MO x catalysts are shown in the Supplementary data, Fig. S15, and those for the Au/MO x /γ-Al2O3 catalysts are shown in Fig. S16. Assignments are consistent with the binding energies found in the literature [63]. The 4f 7/2 data for the four 5wt% Au/MO x catalysts all show the presence of Au(I) in addition to Au(0) following catalysis. Au/NiO was also examined prior to catalysis, and the presence of Au(III) was also detected. However, this was not observed in the spent catalyst, indicating that it was consumed during the reaction. The Au/MO x /γ-Al2O3 catalysts were examined both prior to and following the complete oxidation of isobutane. Except for Au/NiO/γ-Al2O3, the only common species detected in the Au/MO x /γ-Al2O3 catalysts was Au(0). This suggests that it is the gold nanoparticles that are important in the oxidation catalysis, and not any higher oxidation states of gold. Likewise, Au/γ-Al2O3 only showed Au(0) following catalysis. The presence of Au(0) in the spent Au/MO x catalysts is consistent with gold nanoparticles being the important component in the oxidation of isobutane. The presence of higher oxidation states of gold appears to be primarily associated with the MO x (β-MnO2, α-Fe2O3, Co3O4 and NiO) phases, and are either formed during the initial thermolysis to remove the n-C6S− ligands from the preformed n-C6SAu nanoparticles, and/or are stabilized during the complete oxidation of isobutane. Other than the appearance of some Au(I) in the spent Au/NiO/γ-Al2O3 catalyst, no higher oxidation states of gold are formed in the presence of γ-Al2O3. This suggests that the formation of Au(I) and Au(III) are associated with thermal effects during n-C6S− loss, but that Au(I), unlike Au(III), is not consumed during the catalysis reaction. The presence of the γ-Al2O3 may simply offer a means of thermal dissipation during exothermic n-C6S− ligand loss, and during the exothermic oxidation of isobutane. However, the formation of some Au(I) in the spent Au/NiO catalyst and its presence in Au/NiO/γ-Al2O3 both before and after catalysis does indicate the presence of a strong oxidant, which is suggested to be surface Ni3+ in the NiO. 4 Conclusions The complete oxidation of isobutane over a range of first row transition metal oxide catalysts has been studied, resulting in the order Co3O4 >β-MnO2 >α-Fe2O3, with NiO in a variable position depending on the activity parameter considered (e.g., T i, T 100%). It is suggested that this is related to the varying Ni3+ content found in non-stoichiometric NiO with temperature. The activity data is consistent with TG/DTA studies performed under a 10% H2/N2 atmosphere. Addition of gold nanoparticles (5wt%) by n-C6SAu nanoparticles results in enhanced catalytic activity through a gold-enhanced Mars-van Krevelen mechanism, although this depends on the (poisoning) effect of the adsorbed sulfate on the metal oxide, which forms as a result of thermolysis in air, a process employed to remove the stabilizing n-C6S− ligands of the preformed n-C6SAu nanoparticles. The sulfate appears to block the metal reoxidation step in the Mars-van Krevelen reaction mechanism. The size of the gold nanoparticles is controlled by the type of metal oxide and its specific surface area, with larger surface areas impeding aggregation, as well as on the temperatures experienced during the oxidation reaction. This makes it difficult to correlate activity with the size of the gold nanoparticles, including properties such as gold surface area and the perimeter of the metal oxide-gold interface when comparing a range of catalysts. However, when dealing with a controlled system, such as varying gold nanoparticle size on a single metal oxide of known surface area, E app and T i were shown to depend on the gold nanoparticle size in the case of NiO. The multicomponent catalysts Au/MO x /γ-Al2O3 (M=Mn, Fe, Co, Ni) result in greater catalytic activity compared to the parent Au/γ-Al2O3 catalyst. However, the supported MO x /γ-Al2O3 and Au/MO x /γ-Al2O3 catalysts do not offer any advantage over the unsupported MO x and Au/MO x catalysts alone for the complete oxidation of isobutane, although the effects of the residual sulfate hinder comparisons for some catalyst systems. Gold 4f 7/2 XPS data suggest that it is the gold nanoparticles, i.e., Au(0), that are important in the reaction mechanism, rather than higher oxidation states of gold, based on the species present both prior to and following catalysis. coredata.dc:description: The complete oxidation of isobutane has been studied using the oxidation catalysts β-MnO2, α-Fe2O3, Co3O4 and NiO, prior to and following addition of 5wt% Au nanoparticles. The activity order is Co3O4 >β-MnO2 >α-Fe2O3, with the position of NiO dependent on the Ni3+ content which changes with temperature. Preformed n-hexanethiolate-stabilized gold nanoparticles, following adsorption and thermolysis in air, introduce a small amount of sulfur as adsorbed sulfate. The sulfate appears to block the reoxidation step in the Mars-van Krevelen mechanism. This can have a significant effect on catalytic activity, as observed for β-MnO2. TEM/STEM studies indicate that gold nanoparticles of 2–4nm in diameter form, which depends on the identity of the metal oxide and its specific surface area. Gold nanoparticle size effects have been studied on NiO, and show that the apparent activation energy and temperature of initial reaction depend on nanoparticle size. Comparisons of the multicomponent Au/MO x /γ-Al2O3 (M:Al=1:10) catalysts, where M=Mn, Fe, Co, Ni, have also been studied, and all are more active catalysts than Au/γ-Al2O3, but less active than the unsupported catalysts. Gold 4f 7/2 XPS studies on Au/MO x and Au/MO x /γ-Al2O3 have shown that the only common species present is Au(0), suggesting that higher oxidation states of Au are not important in oxidation catalysis.
coredata.dc:title: The effects of gold nanoparticles obtained from the thermolysis of n-hexanethiolate-stabilized gold nanoparticles on isobutane oxidation over metal oxide catalysts
